snippet: The results of Takata-commissioned research on a compound thought to be at the root of an airbag defect were not disclosed to regulators for more than two years.

byline.original: By DANIELLE IVORY and HIROKO TABUCHI

abstract: Company employees say Honda and Takata kept investigation into exploding Takata airbags and results pointing to faulty design quiet during recall of hundreds of thousands of vehicles over several years; federal officials say companies broke no laws since airbags were not subject of official investigation, but authorities have criticized companies' recalcitrance due to seriousness of defect.
lead_paragraph: The results of Takata-commissioned research on a compound thought to be at the root of an airbag defect were not disclosed to regulators for more than two years.

headline.print_headline: Airbag Study Was Kept Quiet During Recalls
headline.main: Takata and Honda Kept Quiet on Study That Questioned Airbag Propellant
